The key approach to @global.prog_name is that we draw on the shared wisdom and experience of our parents to help brainstorm and problem-solve the challenges we want to tackle at home. That means that we want everybody to pool their ideas so that we all develop and practice new skills. 

Parents are welcome to share in whatever way they are most comfortable: text or audio messages. 

The foundation for this programme is the idea that parents want to strengthen their relationships with their kids in order to build a healthy home. That’s why they are here! 

The programme encourages positive interactions between parents and kids by helping parents to develop skills around praising good behaviour, spending quality time, and talking about feelings. 

If parents are spending time reinforcing positive behaviours with praise, then parents will have to do less work managing problem behaviours. 

Other skills that the programme introduces to manage unwanted behaviours include ignoring and redirecting negative attention-seeking behaviours and introducing consequences. 

The notion that children are kept safe by establishing rules and routines, planning for any risks, and surrounding them with as much care as possible underscores the entire programme.

The programme uses online messaging platforms that are familiar to parents (e.g., WhatsApp, Viber, Telegram, Facebook Messenger, etc.). 

The main teaching method in this programme is to do activities together to enable learning through doing instead of learning through being told. This method helps participants to learn both during the sessions and at home. 

This is because we all remember and understand things much better when we have done them ourselves.
text:
E aserkamentu klave pa @global.prog_name ta, ku nos ta usa e sabiduria i eksperensia kompartí di nos mayornan pa yuda pensa huntu i resolvé e retonan ku nos ke atendé na kas. Esei ta nifiká ku nos ke pa tur hende pone nan ideanan huntu pa nos tur desaroyá i praktiká abilidatnan nobo.

Mayornan ta bon biní pa kompartí na kualke manera ku nan ta mas kómodo: mensahenan di teksto òf oudio.

E fundeshi pa e programa akí ta e idea ku mayornan ke fortalesé nan relashonnan ku nan yunan pa asina konstruí un hogar salú. Ta p’esei nan ta akí!

E programa ta enkurashá interakshonnan positivo entre mayornan i muchanan dor di yuda mayornan desaroyá abilidatnan ku ta enserá elogiá bon komportashon, pasa tempu di kalidat i papia tokante sintimentunan.

Si mayornan ta dediká tempu na reforsá komportashonnan positivo ku elogio, e ora ei mayornan lo mester hasi ménos trabou pa manehá komportashonnan problemátiko.

Otro abilidatnan ku e programa ta introdusí pa manehá komportashonnan no-deseá ta inkluí ignorá i desviá komportashonnan negativo di buska atenshon i introdusí konsekuensianan.

E idea pa tene muchanan seif dor di establesé reglanan i rutinanan, plania pa kualke riesgo, i rondoná nan ku mas tantu kuido posibel ta sirbi komo un base pa henter e programa.

E programa ta usa plataformanan di mensahe 'online' ku ta konosí pa mayornan (p.e., WhatsApp, Viber, Telegram, Facebook Messenger, èts.).

E método prinsipal di enseñansa den e programa akí ta pa hasi aktividatnan huntu pa siña dor di hasi, na lugá di siña dor di bisá bo kiko pa hasi. E método akí ta yuda e partisipantenan siña tantu durante e seshonnan komo na kas.

Esaki ta pasobra nos tur ta kòrda i komprondé kosnan muchu mas mihó ora nos mes hasi nan.
note: The string @global.prog_name should not be translated.

SourceText:
_Only if you are delivering in-person session for your parent group_

- Make sure all materials and venues are prepared in advance of the session.

- Greet caregivers when they arrive at the session.

- Create a safe, comfortable and empathetic space, make them feel welcome with a smile and eye contact.

- Understand the relationship between the parent and their children. Remember that each relationship will be different.

- Remember that every child develops at different speeds and stages. 

- Respect what participants share and be aware of different ages, genders, values, and circumstances. 

- Encourage caregivers to share and respond to each other - and praise them when they do it!

- Remind caregivers of group rules when needed.

- Notice when a parent is quiet or struggles with something and provides support. 

- Model the behaviour you want to see among the mothers, fathers, and caregivers. 

- Use energisers to keep live interactions engaging and fun.
text:
_Solamente si bo ta fasilitá seshonnan en persona pa bo grupo di mayor_

- Sòru pa tur material i lugá ta prepará promé ku e seshon.

- Kumindá e edukadónan ora nan yega na e seshon.

- Krea un espasio seif, kómodo i empátiko, laga nan sinti nan mes bon biní ku un sonrisa i hasi kontakto visual.

- Komprondé e relashon entre e mayor i su yunan. Kòrda ku kada relashon lo ta diferente.

- Kòrda ku kada mucha ta desaroyá na diferente ritmo i fase.

- Respetá loke e partisipantenan ta kompartí i ta konsiente di diferente edat, sekso, balornan i sirkunstansia.

- Enkurashá edukadónan pa kompartí i reakshoná riba otro su aporte - i elogiá nan ora nan hasié!

- Kòrda edukadónan riba reglanan di grupo ora ta nesesario.

- Nota ora un mayor ta ketu òf ta lucha ku algu i brinda sosten.

- Duna ehèmpel di e komportashon ku bo ke mira bou di e mamanan, tatanan i edukadónan.

- Usa aktividatnan ku ta duna energia pa tene interakshonnan bibu atraktivo i dibertido.

SourceText:
It’s important to be **well prepared**. This shows respect for the parents and will help ensure that they get as much out of the module as they can. 

Each module begins with ways you can prepare to deliver a session.

Before the day begins:

1️⃣ Ensure you know what needs to take place. 

2️⃣ On Learn with a Story, Home Practice Reminder and Chat Coming Soon that means thinking through when you will send messages.

3️⃣ On Let’s Connect that means re-reading the module you will be giving, scrolling through messages that parents have sent about home practice (if any) and making sure that you are absolutely clear on what needs to take place. 

4️⃣ Go through any notes you have to personalise or direct message parents as necessary. This will also help you to remember what took place and prepare you for the next module.

5️⃣ Ensure that any technology that you need is prepared: Phones charged, videos, recordings and illustration files have been tested and are ready to upload, internet connection secure. Make a back-up plan for any tech failures – including alternative ways to communicate with parents and re-scheduling group sessions if needed.

6️⃣ If you’re creating audio or video files of yourself to upload, make sure that the audio or video message is as clear as possible – they don’t need to be professional, but they do need to communicate clearly! Make sure there’s enough light and that you are clearly visible, don’t change the direction of the video you are shooting (for video), avoid background sounds and speak clearly.
text:
Ta importante pa ta **bon prepará**. Esaki ta mustra rèspèt pa e mayornan i lo yuda nan pa saka mas tantu ku nan por for di e módulo. 

Kada módulo ta kuminsá ku maneranan ku bo por prepará pa fasilitá un seshon.

Promé ku e dia kuminsá:

1️⃣ Sòru pa bo sa kiko mester tuma lugá.

2️⃣ Pa loke ta trata Siña ku un Historia, Rekordatorio di Tarea di Kas i Djis nos ta 'Chat' esei ta nifiká pensa riba ki ora bo ta bai manda mensahenan.

3️⃣ Pa loke ta trata Laga nos Konektá esei ta nifiká bolbe lesa e módulo ku bo ta bai duna, pasa dor di mensahenan ku mayornan a manda tokante nan tarea di kas (si tin) i sòru pa bo ta kompletamente na altura di kiko mester tuma lugá.

4️⃣ Pasa dor di kualke anotashon ku bo tin pa personalisá òf manda un mensahe direkto pa mayornan segun ta nesesario. Esaki lo yudá bo tambe pa kòrda kiko a tuma lugá i prepará pa e siguiente módulo.

5️⃣ Sòru pa kualke teknologia ku bo mester, ta prepará: Telefònnan kargá, vidionan, grabashonnan i failnan di ilustrashon di tèst i kla pa subi e ret, konekshon di internèt sigur. Traha un plan B pa kualke fayo di teknologia – inkluyendo maneranan alternativo pa komuniká ku mayornan i re-programá seshonnan di grupo si ta nesesario.

6️⃣ Si bo ta krea failnan di oudio òf vidio di bo mes pa subi e ret, sòru pa e mensahe di oudio òf vidio ta mas kla posibel – nan no mester ta profeshonal, pero nan mester trese e mensahe ku klaridat! Sòru pa tin sufisiente lus i ku bo ta bon visibel, no kambia e direkshon di e vidio ku bo ta grabando (ora ta trata vidio), evitá zonidonan di fondo i papia kla.

SourceText:
You’ll help parents learn one new parenting skill each week by sharing lesson content across the week.

📹 **What You’ll Share**

Each week, you’ll send videos with parenting tips. These tips are the main part of the module.

Most videos include two short stories:
👶 One for children aged 2–9
🧑‍🎓 One for teens aged 10–17

👉 If your group includes only young children or only teens, you’ll send one story video.
👉 If your group includes both, you’ll send both videos.


📖 **What’s in the videos?**

Each story uses illustrations to show real-life situations.

A short explainer at the end helps parents reflect and understand the parenting tips.

These stories make it easier for parents to relate to the skill and think about how to use it at home.


🏡 **Home Practice**

Each week, parents are encouraged to try the tips at home.

This is a key part of the programme!

It helps parents practice new skills in real life.

You can support them by helping them plan:
🕓 When to try the tip
📍 Where they can do it
📝 How they might do it with their child
text:
Lo bo yuda mayornan siña un abilidat nobo di edukashon familiar tur siman dor di kompartí kontenido di lès durante henter siman.

📹 **Kiko Bo Ta Kompartí**

Tur siman, bo ta manda videonan ku tepnan di edukashon familiar. E tepnan akí ta e parti prinsipal di e módulo.

Mayoria di e videonan ta inkluí dos kuenta kòrtiku:
👶 Un pa muchanan di 2–9 aña di edat.
🧑‍🎓 Un pa tinernan di edat 10–17

👉 Si bo grupo ta inkluí solamente mucha chikitu òf solamente tiner, bo ta manda un video di historia.
👉 Si bo grupo ta inkluí tur dos, bo ta manda tur dos video.


📖 **Kiko tin den e Videonan?**

Kada historia ta usa ilustrashonnan pa mustra situashonnan di bida real.

Un splikashon kòrtiku na final ta yuda mayornan reflehá i komprondé e tepnan di edukashon familiar.

E historianan akí ta hasié mas fásil pa mayornan komprondé e abilidat i pensa kon pa us’é na kas.


🏡 **Tarea di Kas**

Tur siman, ta enkurashá mayornan pa purba e tepnan na kas.

Esaki ta un parti klave di e programa!

E ta yuda mayornan praktiká abilidatnan nobo den bida real.

Bo por sostené nan dor di yuda nan plania:
🕓 Ki ora pa purba e tep
📍Unda nan por hasié
📝 Kon nan por hasié ku nan yu

SourceText:
Encourage parents to practice their parenting tips at home by reminding them that the key to changing behaviours and attitudes is to practice them in their own lives. 

You will send two reminders during the week:
text:
Enkurashá mayornan pa praktiká nan tepnan di edukashon familiar na kas dor di kòrda nan ku e yabi pa kambia komportashon i aktitut ta pa praktiká nan den nan mes bida.

Lo bo manda dos rekordatorio durante siman:

SourceText:
**Welcome and Check-in** 

Begin each session with a message that welcomes the parents to the session chat. 

Check-in to make sure that everyone is ready to begin the session. This is easier said than done when you are online! You may want to ask if that everybody’s connection is steady and that they are comfortable and sitting somewhere where they can ‘chat’. 

Praise parents for making the effort to join the session and let them know you are excited to get going!

Take responsibility for ensuring that everybody’s contribution is heard. This means making sure you understand the language needs and abilities of participants before you begin – will everybody be typing? Or will there be a mix of audio and text from parents?

Framing the session: It’s important to let parents know what to expect from each session. Start each session by letting them know what home activity are we discussing.

Ask parents how they are feeling today. You can model this process by sending a message that shares about how you are feeling today and describing where you are feeling it in your body, for example: “Today I am tired! I was up at night with my child. I can feel it in my sore, heavy feet, which don’t seem to want to walk anywhere very fast!”


**Checking in on home activity**

Start by reminding parents what last week’s parenting tip was. Ask a simple question to see who tried it — like a 👍 or “Yes/Not yet.” Keep it light and supportive. Praise parents who gave it a try, even if it was just a little. Encourage those who didn’t — remind them it’s okay to try again this week.

**Voting on a challenge to discuss** 

After checking in on the home activity, give parents a chance to vote on a common challenge they may have faced. Share 3–4 relatable options. This helps parents feel seen and makes it easy to respond.

Let them know it’s normal to face challenges — voting creates a safe space to talk about what was hard.
text:
**Bon Bini i Chèk-in**

Kuminsá kada seshon ku un mensahe ku ta yama e mayornan bon biní na e seshon di 'chat'.

'Chèk-in' pa sigurá bo mes ku tur hende ta kla pa kuminsá e seshon. Esaki ta mas fásil pa bisa ku hasi ora bo ta 'online'! Bo por puntra si e konekshon di tur hende ta stabil i ku nan ta sinti nan mes kómodo i si nan ta sintá un kaminda ku nan por 'chat'.

Elogiá mayornan pa a hasi e esfuerso pa djòin e seshon i laga nan sa ku bo ta entusiasmá pa kuminsá!

Tuma responsabilidat pa perkurá pa tur hende skucha otro su kontribushon. Esaki ta nifiká sòru ku bo ta komprondé e nesesidatnan i abilidatnan di idioma di e partisipantenan promé ku bo kuminsá – tur hende lo taip? Òf lo tin un meskla di oudio i teksto di mayornan?
 
Strukturá e seshon: Ta importante pa laga mayornan sa kiko por spera di kada seshon. Kuminsá kada seshon dor di laga nan sa di ki tepnan di edukashon familiar lo bo papia awe i si nan por spera di mira ilustrashonnan, vidio... òf tur dos! 

Puntra mayornan kon nan ta sinti awe. Bo por duna ehèmpel di e proseso akí dor di manda un mensahe tokante kon abo ta sinti awe i deskribí unda bo ta sintié den bo kurpa, por ehèmpel: “Awe mi ta kansá! Mi a keda lantá anochi ku mi yu. Mi por sintié den mi pianan due i pisá, ku no ta parse di ke kana muchu lihé bai niun kaminda!”

**Revisá tarea pa hasi na kas**

Kuminsá dor di kòrda mayornan kiko tabata e tep di edukashon familiar di siman pasá. Hasi un pregunta simpel pa wak ken a purba esaki — manera un 👍 òf “Si/Ainda nò.” Mantené esaki simpel i duna sosten. Elogiá mayornan ku a purba, asta si e tabata djis un tiki. Enkurashá esnan ku no a hasié — kòrda nan ku ta bon pa purba atrobe e siman akí.

**Vota riba un reto pa diskutí**

Despues di a chèk kon a bai ku e tarea pa hasi na kas, duna mayornan un chèns pa vota riba un reto komun ku podisé nan a topa. Kompartí 3–4 opshon ku nan por relashoná kuné. Esaki ta yuda mayornan sinti ku tin atenshon pa nan i ta hasié fásil pa nan reakshoná.

Laga nan sa ku ta normal pa enfrentá retonan — votashon ta krea un espasio seif pa papia tokante loke tabata difísil.

SourceText:
**Discussing Solution** 
Before arriving at a solution, it is useful to explore the challenge in depth.

_**Tips for exploring questions and challenges**_

Use open-ended questions! So instead of saying “did you do this tip?” ask “How did the tip work in your home?” 

Try using Who? What? When? Why? Where? And How?

Remember to redirect what the participant says to topics related to the programme.

Praise, praise, and praise some more! When you praise the parents, you demonstrate how praising works and help to promote the positive while parents are tackling challenges.

The stages of problem solving can be useful to develop a specific pool of possible solutions to the challenges that are being discussed. 

Brainstorm solutions: Start the process with a quick brainstorm for possible solutions. Invite all parents to contribute any ideas that they think will work. If they are struggling to contribute, ask them to share strategies that they have tried in their own homes. Make sure you take note of the solutions you would like to discuss further with the group.

Summarise the solutions that have been proposed.

Explore the consequences for the selected solutions: Explore solutions by inviting the group to think about the consequences of each proposed solution. This might include a child’s perspective or experience of each solution; and any feelings that it might evoke. Guide the discussion carefully so that parents have an opportunity to think through what might not work with any problematic suggestions.

Select a solution: Parents pick a solution that they want to try out at home.

→ Remember to praise: Praise parents for working through a challenge and encourage them to try their solution out at home. 


**Open Feedback** 

Invite parents to share their experience from home – ensuring that each parent that wants to share gets a chance to do so. Parents can share success stories as well as any challenges that came up while they were practicing at home. 

Connect the success to the building block for that parenting tip. This will help to remind and reinforce the building blocks for that parenting tip.

Invite the group to then discuss the challenge(s) that have been shared. Select one of the challenges shared by the parents. Follow the steps of “Discussing the solution.”

Remember that parents will often expect facilitators to have all of the answers – but parents are the experts in their own lives and have a lot of experience to draw from in sharing their own solutions. This will help circulate new ideas to the group.


**Take a Pause and Closing**

Take a Pause is an opportunity for parents to reconnect with their breathing and themselves. It’s a quiet moment at the end of the session that they can also use at home when they are feeling stressed.

Closing the session is an opportunity to pull out the most important content from the session. Most importantly, closing the session is an opportunity to tell parents what they are doing right! Thank parents for sharing and reminding them all how difficult it can be to try new things. Praise, praise, praise them for the work they are doing to make themselves and their families healthier and happier!
text:
**Diskutí Solushon**
Promé ku yega na un solushon, ta útil pa eksplorá e reto profundamente.

_**Tepnan pa eksplorá preguntanan i retonan**_

Usa preguntanan habrí! Pues en bes di bisa “bo a hasi e tep akí?” puntra “Kon e tep a funshoná den bo kas?”

Purba usa Ken? Kiko? Ki ora? Dikon? Na unda? I Kon?

Kòrda redirigí loke e partisipante ta bisa na tópikonan relashoná ku e programa.

Elogiá, elogiá i elogiá un tiki mas! Ora bo ta elogiá e mayornan, bo ta demostrá kon elogio ta funshoná i ta yuda promové loke ta positivo miéntras mayornan ta atendé ku retonan.

E fasenan di solushoná problema por ta útil pa desaroyá un grupo spesífiko di posibel solushonnan pa e retonan ku a diskutí.

Pensa solushonnan: Kuminsá e proseso ku un 'brainstorm' rápido pa posibel solushonnan. Invitá tur mayor pa kontribuí ku kualke idea ku nan ta kere lo funshoná. Si nan tin difikultat pa kontribuí, pidi nan pa kompartí strategianan ku nan a yega di purba den nan mes kas. Sòru pa bo nota e solushonnan ku bo ke sigui diskutí ku e grupo.

Resumí e solushonnan ku e mayornan a proponé.

Eksplorá e konsekuensianan pa e solushonnan skohí: Eksplorá solushonnan dor di invitá e grupo pa pensa riba e konsekuensianan di kada solushon proponé. Esaki por inkluí e perspektiva òf eksperensia di un mucha relatá na kada solushon; i kualke sintimentu ku esaki por trese kuné. Guia e diskushon kuidadosamente pa asina mayornan tin un oportunidat pa pensa riba kiko kisas lo no funshoná ku kualke sugerensia problemátiko.

Skohe un solushon: Mayornan ta skohe un solushon ku nan ke purba na kas.

→ Kòrda elogiá: Elogiá mayornan pa traha riba un reto i enkurashá nan pa purba nan solushon na kas.


** Habri posibilidat pa duna 'Feedback'**

Invitá mayornan pa kompartí nan eksperensia for di kas – dor di  sigurá ku kada mayor ku ke kompartí ta haña un chèns pa hasi esaki. Mayornan por kompartí historianan di éksito i tambe kualke reto ku a bini dilanti miéntras nan tabata praktiká na kas.

Konektá e éksito na e komponentenan básiko pa e tep di edukashon familiar ei. Esaki lo yuda pa nan kòrda i pa reforsá e komponentenan básiko pa e tep di edukashon familiar ei.

Invitá e grupo pa despues papia tokante e reto(nan) ku mayornan a kompartí. Skohe un di e retonan ku e mayornan a kompartí. Sigui e pasonan di “Diskutí e solushon.”

Kòrda ku mayornan hopi bia lo spera ku fasilitadónan tin tur kontesta – pero mayornan ta e ekspertonan den nan mes bida i tin hopi eksperensia pa kai bèk ariba ora nan kompartí nan mes solushonnan. Esaki lo yuda sirkulá ideanan nobo den e grupo.


**Tuma un Pousa i Klousura**

Tuma un Pousa ta un oportunidat pa mayornan rekonektá ku nan halamentu di rosea i ku nan mes. E ta un momentu trankil na final di e seshon ku nan por usa tambe na kas ora nan ta sinti strès.

Klousura di e seshon ta un oportunidat pa saka e kontenido mas importante for di e seshon. Mas importante ainda, sera e seshon ta un oportunidat pa bisa mayornan kiko nan ta hasi korekto! Gradisí mayornan pa a kompartí i rekordá nan tur, kon difísil purba kosnan nobo por ta. Elogiá, elogiá i elogiá nan pa e trabou ku nan ta hasi pa hasi nan mes i nan famia mas saludabel i felis!

SourceText:
At the end of every Let’s Connect session, you will be asked to complete a short report in the app. This includes recording parent attendance, reflecting on how the session went, and noting any challenges you faced and what you might try differently next time.

These reports are not just about record-keeping—they are a chance for you to pause, reflect, and learn from your own experience. Each session brings something new, and taking a few minutes to capture your thoughts can help you build confidence, celebrate what went well, and identify small changes that can make the next session even smoother.

Based on the attendance you record, the Actions tab will highlight parents who have missed two sessions in a row. This makes it easier for you to notice families who might need some extra encouragement. By reaching out early, you can help them feel supported and keep them engaged in the programme.
text:
Na final di kada seshon di Laga nos Konektá, lo pidí bo pa kompletá un rapòrt kòrtiku den e aplikashon. Esaki ta inkluí anotá presensia di mayornan, reflehá riba kon e seshon a bai i anotá kualke reto ku bo a topa i kiko bo por purba hasi diferente otro biaha.

E rapòrtnan akí no ta djis tokante mantenshon di registro—nan ta un chèns pa bo para ketu, reflehá i siña for di bo propio eksperensia. Kada seshon ta trese algu nobo, i tumando algun minüt pa kapta bo pensamentunan por yuda bo krea konfiansa, selebrá loke a bai bon, i identifiká kambionan chikí ku por hasi pa e siguiente seshon kana mas mihó ainda.

A base di e asistensia ku bo ta registrá, e página di Akshonnan lo "highlight" e mayornan, ku a pèrdè dos seshon tras di otro. Esaki ta hasié mas fásil pa bo nota famianan ku kisas bo mester enkurashá èkstra. Dor di hasi kontakto lihé, bo por yuda nan sinti nan mes sostené i bo ta tene nan enbolbí den e programa.

SourceText:
Once you have selected a volunteer to be group admin, schedule a WhatsApp call with them.

When you’re done with the call, you can send the guidelines as messages to remind them what you discussed.
text:
Unabes bo a selektá un boluntario pa ta atministradó di grupo, programá un yamada di WhatsApp kuné.

Ora bo kaba ku e yamada, bo por manda e reglanan komo mensahenan pa rekordá nan riba kiko bo a papia.

SourceText:
If parents or group admins reach out to you after the group has ended, it means that you have been helpful to them, which is amazing! 

Parents may see you as a source of support outside of @global.prog_name, but it is important to keep things balanced. 

Share this message to gently guide the parents to other places for support.
text:
Si mayornan òf atministradónan di grupo yega serka bo despues ku e grupo a kaba, esei ta nifiká ku bo a yuda nan, loke ta asombroso!

Mayornan por mirá bo komo un fuente di sosten pafó di @global.prog_name, pero ta importante pa tene kosnan balansá.

Kompartí e mensahe akí pa guia e mayornan amablemente na otro lugánan pa sosten.
note: The string @global.prog_name, should not be translated.

SourceText: After your call with the new group admin, you can share these prompts to support them with leading the chat sessions.
text: Despues di bo yamada ku e atministradó nobo di e grupo, bo por kompartí e preguntanan akí pa sostené nan ku e liderazgo di e seshonnan di kòmbersashon.

SourceText:
It may be difficult to find volunteers to become group admin. If no one volunteers to lead the group, you can send the message below to close the group. 

Wait a couple days before closing because someone might still volunteer!
text:
Por ta difísil pa haña boluntarionan pa bira atministradó di grupo. Si niun hende no bira boluntario pa dirigí e grupo, bo por manda e mensahe aki bou pa sera e grupo. 

Warda un par di dia promé ku sera pasobra podidsé un hende por ke bira boluntario ainda!

SourceText:
This app will guide you on what to do each week. It describes the activities in detail. It provides possible questions that you can ask for discussions and parenting stories.
 
However, the content of the programme is only a small part of what it takes to deliver @global.prog_name. 
Much of the benefit that your parents will receive comes from the way that you deliver it. 

**There are 8 core Principles to facilitating @global.prog_name in the best possible way**:
text:
E aplikashon akí lo guia bo riba kiko pa hasi tur siman. E ta deskribí e aktividatnan den detaye. E ta duná bo posibel preguntanan ku bo por hasi pa diskushonnan i historianan di edukashon familiar.
 
Sinembargo, e kontenido di e programa ta solamente un parti chikí di loke ta nesesario pa fasilitá @global.prog_name. 
Hopi di e benefisio ku bo mayornan lo risibí ta bini di e manera ku bo ta fasilitá esaki. 

**Tin 8 Prinsipio prinsipal pa fasilitá @global.prog_name na e mihó manera posibel**:

SourceText:
1️⃣ Use a collaborative approach to learning.

2️⃣ Model the behaviour you want to see in the way that you behave towards participants.

3️⃣ Practice A-E-C-P: Accept, Explore, Connect, and Practice. 

4️⃣ Be aware of child developmental stages. 
 
5️⃣ Go at your participants’ pace.

6️⃣ Come prepared for each session. 

7️⃣ Make @global.prog_name a happy place to learn.

8️⃣ Don’t be afraid to have fun!
text:
1️⃣ Usa un aserkamentu kolaborativo pa siña.

2️⃣ Duna ehèmpel di e komportashon ku bo ke mira dor di e manera ku bo ta komportá bo mes ku partisipantenan.

3️⃣ Praktiká A-E-K-P: Aseptá, Eksplorá, Konektá i Praktiká. 

4️⃣ Tene kuenta ku e fasenan di desaroyo di mucha. 
 
5️⃣ Bai segun e ritmo di bo partisipantenan.

6️⃣ Bin prepará pa kada seshon. 

7️⃣ Hasi @global.prog_name un lugá dushi pa siña.

8️⃣ No tene miedu di dibertí!
note: The string @global.prog_name should not be translated.

SourceText:
In some programmes, facilitators tell participants what to do and why it is important. Participants are used to this because many education systems are delivered in a didactic, teacher-knows-best manner. 

In the @global.prog_name, we do things differently. We like to think of this as a collaborative approach to learning. As facilitators, we are **collaborators or partners** working with parents to identify plans and practice solutions that will help them to improve life at home.
**It is helpful to think of the participants as the experts.**
 
Many of the parents will already be practicing lots of positive ways of parenting with their children. Others will be able to identify ways of improving their parenting on their own with guidance. **Our job is to help parents learn for themselves how to achieve their goals.**
This sometimes means we have to work harder to ask the right sort of open-ended questions that will help participants work out the benefits of positive parenting and relationship building. **When participants are able to teach themselves on how to relate and behave, they learn a skill that will help them for a long time after the programme ends.**
text:
Den sierto programa, fasilitadónan ta bisa partisipantenan kiko pa hasi i dikon e ta importante. Partisipantenan ta kustumbrá ku esaki pasobra ta duna hopi sistema di edukashon na un manera didáktiko, kaminda ta e maestro sa mihó. 

Den @global.prog_name, nos ta hasi kosnan diferente. Nos ta mira esaki komo un aserkamentu di kolaborashon pa siña. Komo fasilitadó, nos ta **kolaboradó òf partner** ku ta traha ku mayornan pa identifiká plannan i praktiká solushonnan ku lo yuda nan mehorá bida na kas.
**Ta bon pa pensa riba e partisipantenan komo e ekspertonan.**

Hopi di e mayornan ya kaba lo ta praktiká hopi manera positivo di edukashon familiar ku nan yunan. Otronan lo por identifiká maneranan di mehorá nan edukashon familiar riba nan mes, ku guia. **Nos trabou ta pa yuda mayornan siña pa nan mes kon pa logra nan metanan.**
Tin bia esaki ta nifiká ku nos mester traha mas duru pa hasi e tipo di preguntanan habrí korekto, ku lo yuda e partisipantenan traha riba e benefisionan di edukashon familiar positivo i di konstruí relashon. **Ora partisipantenan por siña nan mes kon pa relashoná i komportá nan mes, nan ta siña un abilidat ku lo yuda nan pa hopi tempu despues ku e programa a kaba.**
note: The string @global.prog_name, should not be translated.

SourceText:
The modelling principle is at the foundation of how we deliver the @global.prog_name. 
If we lead sessions in a collaborative approach, praise parents often, practice active listening (by acknowledging messages), and use positive instructions, parents will do the same with their children. Likewise, if we tell parents what to do, criticize them, ignore their needs or concerns, or only say what we do not want them to do, they will do the same.

Facilitators need to model all the different Core Principles in this programme. 

For example, when you praise your participants, do not add any buts, ifs, or any other criticisms! Use transition warnings. Give positive, specific instructions that say the behaviour you want to see in the participants. Some behaviours may need to be addressed directly such as participants being offensive to an individual or the group.

Use praise to encourage participants to arrive on time for sessions, to complete their home activities, and when they accomplish something very challenging. Practice Taking a Pause to help reduce your own stress.

The participants will learn from your example and begin to mirror your behaviour, too.

**It really works!**
text:
E prinsipio di duna ehèmpel ta forma e fundeshi di kon nos ta implementá @global.prog_name. Si nos guia seshonnan den un aserkamentu di kolaborashon, elogiá mayornan ku frekuensia, praktiká skucha aktivo (dor di rekonosé e mensahe) i usa instrukshonnan positivo, mayornan lo hasi meskos ku nan yunan. Asina tambe, si nos bisa mayornan kiko pa hasi, kritiká nan, ignorá nan nesesidatnan òf preokupashonnan, òf solamente bisa loke nos no ke pa nan hasi, nan lo hasi meskos.

Fasilitadónan tin di duna ehèmpel di tur e diferente Prinsipionan Prinispal den e programa akí.

Por ehèmpel, ora bo ta elogiá bo partisipantenan, no agregá ningun 'pero', 'si', òf ningun otro krítika! Usa atvertensia di transishon. Duna instrukshonnan positivo i spesífiko ku ta indiká e komportashon ku bo ke mira den e partisipantenan. Lo mester atendé sierto komportashon direktamente manera ora ta trata partisipantenan ku ta ofendé un individuo òf e grupo.

Usa elogio pa enkurashá partisipantenan pa yega na tempu pa seshonnan, pa kompletá nan aktividatnan di kas i ora nan logra algu hopi difísil. Praktiká Tuma un Pousa pa yuda redusí bo propio strès.

E partisipantenan lo siña for di bo ehèmpel i kuminsá reflehá bo komportashon tambe.

**E ta funshoná di bèrdat!**
note: The string @global.prog_name. should not be translated.

SourceText:
The @global.prog_name introduces many concepts and practices that are new to parents. Sometimes, participants will initially resist learning a new approach with their children. Other times, they will have difficulty understanding some of the more complex practices like distinguishing between punishment and discipline. Facilitators should always go at the participants’ pace when delivering the programme. 

Make sure that the participants in your group have learned a specific parenting or relationship building skill before moving on to the next one.
text:
E @global.prog_name ta introdusí hopi konsepto i práktika ku ta nobo pa mayornan. Tin bia, partisipantenan lo resistí na promé instante pa siña un aserkamentu nobo ku nan yunan. Otro bia, nan lo tin difikultat pa komprondé algun di e práktikanan mas kompleho manera distinguí entre straf i disiplina. Fasilitadónan semper mester bai segun e ritmo di e partisipantenan ora di fasilitá e programa.

Sòru pa e partisipantenan den bo grupo a siña un abilidat spesífiko di edukashon familiar òf di konstruí relashon promé ku pasa pa e siguiente.
note: The string @global.prog_name should not be translated.

SourceText:
A-E-C-P is a core building block in the collaborative approach to facilitating the @global.prog_name. It is also important to model Active Listening so that parents begin to do the same with their own children. 
We like to think of 4 key steps facilitating a discussion with the participants:  Acceptance, Exploration, Connection, and Practice.
text:
A-E-K-P ta un komponente básiko esensial den e aserkamentu di kolaborashon pa fasilitá e @global.prog_name. Tambe ta importante pa duna ehèmpel di Skucha Aktivo pa asina mayornan kuminsá hasi meskos ku nan mes yunan.
Nos ta usa 4 stap klave ku ta fasilitá un diskushon ku e partisipantenan: Aseptá, Eksplorá, Konektá i Práktika.
note: The string @global.prog_name. should not be translated.

SourceText:
It is important to be aware of different competencies and characteristics of children at different stages. 
The characteristics of children can shape parents’ expectations, goals, and activities with their children. 

It may be that the challenges and problems that parents face are rooted in expecting children to behave in ways that they are not yet developmentally ready for.
text:
Ta importante pa ta konsiente ku muchanan tin diferente kompetensia i karakterístika den diferente fase.
E karakterístikanan di muchanan por forma e ekspektativanan, metanan i aktividatnan di mayornan ku nan yunan.

Por ta asina ku e retonan i problemanan ku mayornan ta enfrentá ta basá riba e speransa ku nan tin pa nan yunan komportá nan mes na maneranan ku segun nan desaroyo, nan no ta kla pe ainda .

SourceText:
The more you prepare for each session, the easier time you will have in delivering the material. You will feel more relaxed and be more receptive to how participants are feeling and to their experiences. Read through the manual the night before each session. Write down any notes or reminders that might be helpful for particular activities. Sometimes, the participants will not initially understand what you are asking them if you say the exact words in the manual. It can be helpful to write different ways of asking the discussion questions.
 
If you don’t understand something or forget how to do an activity, ask! You can also message or call another facilitator or your supervisor prior to the module. Look through your participant profiles to review each person’s progress in the programme and to remember any special needs or concerns. This is particularly important for the goals that participants set themselves at the end of the session and the discussion on home activities. Start preparing before the next module. You want to be relaxed and ready to go!

Remember that this app is just a guide. While it is very important that you deliver the programme content as it was designed, it is also important that you find ways to make it your own.
text:
Mas bo prepará pa kada seshon, mas fásil lo ta pa duna e material. Lo bo sintí bo mas relahá i ta mas reseptivo pa e sintimentunan i  eksperensianan di e partisipantenan. Lesa e manual e anochi promé ku kada seshon. Skibi kualke nota òf rekordatorio ku por ta útil pa aktividatnan partikular. Tin bia, e partisipantenan lo no komprondé na promé instante kiko bo ta puntra nan si bo usa e palabranan eksakto ku tin den e manual. E por ta útil pa skibi diferente manera pa hasi e preguntanan di diskushon.
 
Si bo no ta komprondé algu òf bo a lubidá kon pa hasi un aktividat, puntra! Tambe bo por manda un mensahe pa un otro fasilitadó òf bo supervisor promé ku e módulo. Wak den bo profilnan di partisipante pa revisá e progreso di kada persona den e programa i pa kòrda kualke nesesidat òf preokupashon spesial. Esaki ta partikularmente importante pa e metanan ku e partisipantenan ta pone pa nan mes na final di e seshon i e diskushon riba tareanan di kas. Kuminsá prepará promé ku e siguiente módulo. Bo ke ta relahá i kla pa bai!

Kòrda ku e aplikashon akí ta djis un guia. Miéntras ku ta hopi importante pa bo duna e kontenido di e programa manera a diseñá esaki, ta importante tambe pa bo haña un sistema pa duna e materia na un manera ku ta kuadra ku bo.

SourceText:
Participants will want to engage in each module and participate in the activities if you create a group that is welcoming, open, and respectful. Everyone likes a place that is warm and inviting. It can be helpful to think of @global.prog_name as a family itself. 

**Ways in which facilitators can make @global.prog_name group sessions a happy place to learn:**

Respect whatever a participant talks about. Facilitators should be aware and respectful of different ages, genders, values, and circumstances.

Model the behaviour you want from the participants. The group space should be a judgement-free space in which participants feel comfortable sharing sensitive material.

Notice and reflect the ways that participants communicate, help each other, and participate in the sessions.

Invite participation: If you feel a participant is holding back or quiet, ask if he or she wishes to share an opinion or experience.

Make sure that everyone in the group is communicating clearly.

Create a comfortable and welcoming place to meet. Make sure everyone knows how to log-into and interact with the group through the messaging platform you are using.

Establish the communication needs of the participants – are participants using audio? Video?

Notice if participants have challenges that may require adjusting the way they participate in activities.

Praise participants for their effort and dedication.

Model the behaviour you want from the parents in the way that you treat them. 

Praise, respect, and reflect on participants’ contributions.
text:
Partisipantenan lo ke partisipá den kada módulo i partisipá den e aktividatnan si bo krea un grupo ku ta duna e partipante un sintimentu di ta bon biní i ta habrí i respetuoso. Tur hende ta gusta un lugá ku ta kaluroso i kaminda bo ta sinti bo bon biní. E por ta bon pa pensa riba @global.prog_name manera ku ta un famia e ta.

**Maneranan kon fasilitadónan por hasi seshonnan di grupo di @global.prog_name un lugá dushi pa siña:**

Respetá tur loke e partisipantenan ta kompartí. Fasilitadónan mester  ta konsiente i respetá diferente edat, sekso, balornan i sirkunstansianan.

Duna ehèmpel di e komportashon ku bo ke di e partisipantenan. E espasio di grupo mester ta un espasio liber di huisio den kua partisipantenan ta sinti nan mes kómodo pa kompartí material sensitivo.

Tuma nota i reflehá e maneranan ku partisipantenan ta komuniká, yuda otro i partisipá den e seshonnan.

Invitá partisipashon: Si bo ta sinti ku un partisipante ta tene su mes atras òf ketu, puntr’é si e ke kompartí un opinion òf eksperensia.

Sòru pa tur hende den e grupo ta komuniká bon kla.

Krea un lugá kómodo i kaminda ku nan ta sinti nan mes bon biní pa topa. Sòru pa tur hende sa kon pa inisiá seshon 'online' i drenta i interkambiá ku e grupo den e plataforma di mensahe ku bo ta usando.

Establesé e nesesidatnan di komunikashon di e partisipantenan – e partisipantenan lo usa oudio? Vidio?

Tuma nota si e partisipantenan tin retonan ku por rekerí pa ahustá e manera ku nan ta partisipá den aktividatnan.

Elogiá partisipantenan pa nan esfuerso i dedikashon.

Duna ehèmpel di e komportashon ku bo ke di e mayornan dor di e manera ku abo ta trata nan.

Elogiá, respetá i reflehá riba e kontribushonnan di e partisipantenan.

SourceText:
It is important to know the following guidelines for handling disclosures of abuse, neglect, and violence from participants:

1️⃣ **Understand abuse, neglect and exploitation.**

❗ **Abuse** refers to a deliberate act of maltreatment that can damage a boy or girl’s security, wellbeing, dignity and development. Abuse includes all forms of physical, sexual, psychological and emotional maltreatment. (Save the Children definition)

❗ **Violence** against girls and boys is defined as forms of physical or mental violence, damage and abuse, neglect or neglectful treatment or maltreatment or exploitation, including sexual abuse. (Office of the High Commissioner for Human Rights, 1990,
Article 19)

❗ **Child exploitation** refers to using girls and boys for economic or sexual benefit, gratification or profit, often resulting in unjust, cruel and harmful treatment of the girl or boy. (Save the Children definition)

2️⃣ **Know your organisation’s child safeguarding policies and referral procedures.**

📖 All organisations should have or develop child rights safeguarding policies and referral procedures, including details on how to respond appropriately when a caregiver, other adults, girl or boy discloses abuse. 

📝 You should have accurate knowledge of all protocols and response plans. These will tell you what to do within your organisation if a caregiver or girl or boy reports abuse (e.g. who to report to, internal resources for supporting the girl or boy), as well as how to engage outside resources (e.g. local referral pathways, when to engage with authorities). 

🔑 It is your responsibility to act regardless of whether you are responding to disclosures of past and/or present abuse. However, you are not responsible for resolving the situation on your own. It is important that you discuss the situation with your supervisor to agree on what steps to take next.

3️⃣ **Ensure parents know that you are someone who can help.**

🌷Parents participating in your sessions need to know that they can come to you for help, regardless of when the abuse occurred. 

👂You should make sure that they know that they can trust you and that you will listen and support them without judgement or any further harm.
text:
Ta importante pa sa e siguiente reglanan pa manehá divulgashonnan di abusu, negligensia i violensia di partisipantenan:

1️⃣ **Komprondé abusu, negligensia i eksplotashon.**

❗ **Abusu** ta referí na un akto deliberadamente di maltrato ku por daña un mucha hòmber òf mucha muhé su seguridat, bienestar, dignidat i desaroyo. Abusu ta enserá tur forma di maltrato físiko, seksual, sikológiko i emoshonal. (Definishon di Save the Children)

❗ **Violensia** kontra mucha muhé i mucha hòmber ta definí komo formanan di violensia físiko òf mental, daño i abusu, negligensia òf trato negligente òf maltrato òf eksplotashon, inkluyendo abusu seksual. (Ofisina di Alto Komisario pa Derechonan Humano, 1990,
Artíkulo 19)

❗ **Eksplotashon di mucha** ta referí na uso di mucha muhé i mucha hòmber pa benefisio ekonómiko òf seksual, gratifikashon òf ganashi, ku hopi bia ta resulltá den trato inhustu, kruel i dañino di e mucha muhé òf mucha hòmber. (Definishon di Save the Children)

2️⃣ **Konosé e maneho di protekshon di mucha di bo organisashon i e proseduranan di referensia.**

📖 Tur organisashon mester tin òf mester desaroyá maneho di protekshon di derechonan di mucha i proseduranan di referensia, inkluyendo detayenan riba kon pa atendé di forma apropiá si un dunadó di kuido, otro adultonan, mucha muhé òf mucha hòmber revelá abusu.

📝 Bo mester tin konosementu eksakto di tur protokòl i plannan di akshon. Den esakinan tin poné loke mester hasi den bo organisashon si un dunadó di kuido òf mucha muhé òf mucha hòmber raportá abusu (p.e. na ken pa raportá, rekursonan interno pa sostené e mucha muhé òf mucha hòmber), i tambe kon pa enbolbí rekursonan di pafó (p.e. trayektonan di referensia lokal, ki ora pa enbolbí outoridatnan).

🔑 Ta bo responsabilidat pa aktua sin importá si bo ta respondé na revelashonnan di abusu di pasado i/òf presente. Sinembargo, bo no ta responsabel pa resolvé e situashon riba bo mes. Ta importante pa bo papia tokante e situashon ku bo supervisor pa bai di akuerdo riba kua pasonan pa sigui tuma.

3️⃣ **Perkurá pa mayornan sa ku bo ta un hende ku por yuda.**

🌷Mayornan ku ta partisipá na bo seshonnan mester sa ku nan por bini serka bo pa yudansa, sin importá ki ora e abusu a tuma lugá.

👂Bo mester sòru pa nan sa ku nan por konfiá bo i ku lo bo skucha i sostené nan sin huzga nan òf sin mas daño.

SourceText:
**During disclosure:**

💚 Provide a safe environment in which the participant can share their story.

👂 Listen carefully to the participant and take notes: what/when/where/who.

❗ Determine if the participant is in immediate danger and what help is available.

💙 Make sure that the participant feels that you believe him/her.

🌷 Let them know they have done the right thing by sharing their story with you.

✨ Be supportive and free of judgement in your responses – avoid blaming at all times!

➡️ Let the participant know that you will share what he/she told you with your supervisor to find a way to support and protect him/her.

📝 Explain what you are going to do next.

 ✅ Notify @global.supervisor_name

❗Remember that it is not your obligation to solve the situation, but you must report it to your supervisors for follow-up. Don't try to solve it alone.
text:
**Durante di divulgashon:**

💚 Perkurá pa un ambiente seif kaminda e partisipante por kompartí su historia.

👂 Skucha e partisipante bon i tuma nota: kiko/ki ora/unda/ken.

❗ Determiná si e partisipante ta den peliger inmediato i ki yudansa tin disponibel.

💙 Sòru pa e partisipante sinti ku bo ta kere e.

🌷 Lag'é sa ku el a hasi e kos korekto dor di kompartí su historia ku bo.

✨ Duna bo sosten i sòru pa bo kontesta ta liber di huisio – evitá di tira falta na tur momentu!

➡️ Laga e partisipante sa ku lo bo kompartí loke el a bisá bo ku bo supervisor pa haña un manera pa sosten'é i proteh’é.

📝 Splika kiko bo ta bai hasi despues. 

✅ Notifiká @global.supervisor_name

❗Kòrda ku no ta bo obligashon pa solushoná e situashon, pero bo mester informá esaki na bo supervisornan pa por tuma e pasonan nesesario. No purba di solushon’é bo so.
note: The string @global.supervisor_name should not be translated.

SourceText:
**After disclosure:**

❌ Avoid engaging with the alleged abuser – that may make things worse and make next steps difficult. It could also jeopardise future legal proceedings.

🌷 You are not alone. Get help from your supervisor to agree on the next steps.
text:
**Despues di divulgashon:**

❌ Evitá di enbolbí ku e supuesto abusadó – esei por hasi kosnan pió i hasi e siguiente pasonan difísil. Esaki por stroba tambe prosedimentunan legal den futuro.

🌷 Bo no ta bo so. Buska yudansa di bo supervisor pa bai di akuerdo ku e siguiente pasonan.

SourceText:
The first step to building healthier and happier relationships is to spend dedicated time together. When parents spend one-on-one time with their children away from work and household duties and other people, they create space to be available to their child, to get more involved in their lives, and to build trust and communication skills. A strong parent-child relationship requires spending time together in this way.

**Key building blocks for one-on-one time**

The key building blocks for One-on-One time are Day, Play, and Stay:

**DAY**- Try to do it every day
Spend 5 minutes (or more!) One-on-One time with your child each day.

**PLAY** - Let them choose the activity
Tell your child or teen that you would like to spend some time with them and that they can choose what to do or talk about. They might think this is weird at first but will come to enjoy this time with you!

**STAY** - Focus on your child or teen
Switch off TV and put aside phones. Look at your child or teen. Nod or say “I see” to show you are really paying attention. Accept what they say without judging them.
text:
E promé stap pa krea relashonnan mas saludabel i felis ta pa pasa tempu dediká huntu ku otro. Ora mayornan ta pasa tempu huntu ku nan yunan leu for di trabou i trabounan di kas i otro hende, nan ta traha espasio pa ta disponibel pa nan yu, pa ta mas enbolbí den nan bida, i pa krea konfiansa i abilidatnan di komunikashon. Un relashon fuerte entre mayor i yu ta rekerí pa pasa tempu huntu di e manera akí.

**Komponentenan básiko i klave pa tempu abo ku bo yu**

E komponentennan básiko i klave pa Tempu Abo ku Bo Yu ta Dia, Hunga i Keda:

**DIA**- Purba hasié tur dia
Pasa 5 minüt (òf mas!) di Tempu Abo ku Bo Yu tur dia.

**HUNGA** - Laga nan skohe e aktividat
Bisa bo yu òf tiner ku lo bo ke pasa un ratu kuné i ku e por skohe kiko pa hasi òf papia di dje. E por pensa ku esaki ta straño na kuminsamentu pero e lo bin disfrutá di e tempu akí ku bo!

**KEDA** - Enfoká riba bo yu òf tiner
Paga televishon i pone telefònnan un banda. Wak bo yu òf tiner. Sakudí kabes òf bisa “Mi ta mira” pa mustra ku bo ta paga tinu di bèrdat. Aseptá loke nan ta bisa sin husga nan.

SourceText:
Happiness, sadness, anger, disgust, surprise, and fear: We all experience emotions. Because emotions are connected to our thoughts and behaviour, they play an important role in how we make decisions. If we don’t handle emotions well, we risk making bad decisions that can affect our well-being. And when we learn how to handle our emotions, we are more likely to be able to make clear decisions and act in a responsive and nurturing way towards our children, other adults, and ourselves.

Young people who don’t manage their emotions can resort to risky behaviours that can be dangerous for them. It is important for parents to learn to help their children to recognise and manage their strong emotions. 

Talking about difficult emotions is especially important. Difficult emotions like anger can become stressful thoughts and uncontrolled behaviours. Before we can talk about the emotions we are experiencing, just being aware of them can help us to stay present in a moment, which will allow the feelings to run their course and pass. This is also true for children.

When parents name their children’s feelings, or comment on them, it helps children to develop a sense of emotional control. Parents can accept their children’s emotions and communicate with them about what they are experiencing in a calm and supportive way. This will reduce other more potentially risky ways children might turn to in order to escape the feeling.

During Module Two, parents learn about the importance of accepting, naming, and exploring a range of emotions with their children. They learn techniques that will help them to do this effectively. 

**The primary objectives for this week are parents learning and practicing how to talk about their own and their children’s feelings.**
text:
Felisidat, tristesa, rabia, disgustu, sorpresa i miedu: Nos tur ta eksperensiá emoshonnan. Komo ku emoshonnan ta konektá ku nos pensamentunan i komportashon, nan ta hunga un ròl importante den e manera ku nos ta tuma desishon. Si nos no manehá emoshonnan bon, nos ta kore riesgo di tuma mal desishon ku por afektá nos bienestar. I ora nos siña kon pa manehá nos emoshonnan, nos tin mas chèns di tuma desishonnan kla i aktua na un manera reaktivo, sensitivo i kuidadoso ku nos yunan, otro adultonan i nos mes.

Hóbennan ku no ta manehá nan emoshonnan por hasi uso di komportashonnan riesgoso ku por ta peligroso pa nan. Ta importante pa mayornan siña yuda nan yunan rekonosé i manehá nan emoshonnan fuerte.

Papia tokante emoshonnan difísil ta hopi importante. Emoshonnan difísil manera rabia por bira pensamentunan ku ta kousa strès i komportashon deskontrolá. Promé ku nos por papia tokante e emoshonnan ku nos ta eksperenshá, djis dor di ta konsiente di nan, nos por fiha nos atenshon kompletu riba nan i asina sinti ku e sentimentu ta OK i ku e lo disparsé segun tempu pasa. Esaki ta konta pa mucha tambe.

Ora mayornan nombra e sintimentunan di nan yunan, òf komentá riba nan, e ta yuda nan desaroyá un sentido di kòntròl emoshonal. Mayornan por aseptá e emoshonnan di nan yunan i komuniká ku nan tokante loke nan ta eksperenshá na un manera trankil i ku ta sostené nan. Esaki lo redusí ku muchanan por skohe otro maneranan ku potensialmente tin mas riesgo pa skapa di e sintimentu.

Durante Módulo Dos, mayornan ta siña tokante e importansia di aseptá, nombra i eksplorá un skala di emoshon ku nan yunan. Nan ta siña téknikanan ku lo yuda nan hasi esaki efektivamente.

**E ophetivonan prinsipal pa e siman aki ta pa mayornan siña i praktiká kon pa papia tokante nan mes i nan yunan su sintimentunan.**

SourceText:
**Key building blocks for talking about emotions**

The key building blocks for Talking about Emotions are Breathe, Share, Listen, Show, and Seek:

**BREATHE. Slowly. Pause**. 
Before you say anything, slowly breathe in and out. It will calm you and give you a chance to think.

**SHARE how you feel**
This is hard. Many of us were told not to cry or show our feelings to our children. But take a deep breath and calmly tell them how you feel. They will understand better, and also learn from you how to deal with stress. 

**LISTEN to your child or teen**
Allow your child to share their emotions. You can also reflect back what they say to you. Accept that the feeling is okay, even if it is negative.

**SHOW them you care**
This is also hard! Stress makes us focus on ourselves. But our children and teens need our support. Ask them how they feel. Listen to them and comfort them. Try a hug or say, ‘I understand.’ It can change everything.

**SEEK the positive**
Can you and your child or teen think about ideas that might help? Can you do something positive together to take your mind off the stress?
text:
**Komponentenan básiko i klave pa papia tokante emoshonnan**

E komponentenan básiko i klave pa papia tokante Emoshonnan ta Hala Rosea, Kompartí, Skucha, Mustra i Buska:

**HALA ROSEA. Pokopoko. Pousa**. 
Promé ku bo bisa algu, hala rosea aden i sak'é afó pokopoko. E lo trankilisá bo i duná bo un chèns pa pensa.

**KOMPARTÍ kon bo ta sinti**
Esaki ta duru. Hopi di nos a siña pa no yora òf mustra nos sintimentunan na nos yunan. Pero hala rosea profundo i bisa nan trankil kon bo ta sinti. Nan lo komprondé mihó i asina siña di bo kon pa dil ku strès. 

**SKUCHA bo yu òf hóben**
Permití bo yu kompartí su emoshonnan. Bo por reflehá bèk tambe riba loke nan ta bisá bo. Aseptá ku e sintimentu ta bon, asta si e ta negativo.

**MUSTRA nan ku bo ta preokupá**
Esaki tambe ta duru! Strès ta pone nos enfoká riba nos mes. Pero nos muchanan i hóbennan mester di nos sosten. Puntra nan kon nan ta sinti. Skucha nan i konsolá nan. Purba duna un brasa òf bisa, ‘Mi ta komprondé.’ E por kambia tur kos.

**BUSKA e parti positivo**
Abo i bo yu òf hóben por pensa riba ideanan ku por yuda? Boso por hasi algu positivo huntu pa kita bo mente for di e strès?

SourceText:
The objective of this week is to learn how parents can be more effective at getting their children to follow their instructions. They do this in two ways: 

1️⃣ Giving specific, positive, and realistic instructions
2️⃣ Praising their children for following instructions and at other times

When parents give specific, positive, and realistic instructions, children know exactly what behaviour is expected from them. 

For example, “Please put your toys away in the box.” This tells the child exactly what to do by describing the behaviour that is expected. It also considers the capabilities of the child so that the instruction is realistic. 

Compare this to, “Don’t make a mess,” which does not describe the behaviour that a parent would want to see, is not specific, and might not be realistic if the child is not capable of keeping tidy. 

Children also have challenges following many instructions at one time – especially younger children. They are much better at following instructions if they are given one at a time.  Parents can pause for a bit to give children time to follow each instruction before moving to the next one. It may take more time, but this supports children to follow instructions and to remember the task.  

Each child has their own unique characteristics and capabilities. It is important that parents know what is realistic for their children to do when giving them instructions. For instance, it is very hard for children to keep quiet for a whole day but maybe they can keep quiet for 15 minutes while their parents take a call.  

Children also hear better and understand the instructions clearly when parents speak in a calm voice. Yelling at children only increases the tension for everyone. Children are also more likely to follow instructions in a calm way.

Praise is an expression of approval or appreciation. When parents praise their children for following instructions, they are encouraging that behaviour to happen more often. The same works for praising other behaviours. Also, behaviour that is ignored is less likely to happen again. 

With the example above, a parent could say, “Thank you for putting your toys in the box, Joseph,” after he follows the instruction. This will encourage Joseph to continue cleaning up his toys in the future. It also maintains a positive feeling between the parent and Joseph.
text:
E ophetivo di e siman akí ta pa siña mayornan kon pa ta mas efikas pa logra ku nan yunan ta sigui nan instrukshonnan. Nan ta hasi esaki na dos manera:

1️⃣ Duna instrukshonnan spesífiko, positivo i realístiko
2️⃣ Elogiá nan yunan pa sigui instrukshonnan i tambe na otro momentunan

Ora mayornan ta duna instrukshonnan spesífiko, positivo i realístiko, e yunan sa eksaktamente ki komportashon ta spera di nan.

Por ehèmpel, “Por fabor pone bo ko’i hunga den e kaha.” Esaki ta bisa e mucha eksaktamente kiko pa hasi dor di deskribí e komportashon ku ta spera. Tambe mester tene kuenta ku e kapasidat di e mucha pa asina e instrukshon ta realístiko.

Kompará esaki ku, “No brua kos” ku no ta deskribí e komportashon ku un mayor lo ke mira, no ta spesífiko i kisas no ta realístiko si e mucha no ta kapas pa tene tur kos na òrdu.

Mucha tambe tin retonan pa sigui hopi instrukshon pareu – spesialmente muchanan mas yòn. Nan por sigui instrukshonnan muchu mas mihó si duna esakinan un pa un. Mayornan por warda un ratu pa duna yunan tempu pa sigui kada instrukshon promé ku duna e siguiente. E por tuma mas tempu, pero esaki ta yuda e muchanan pa sigui instrukshonnan i pa kòrda e tarea.

Kada mucha tin su propio karakterístika i kapasidatnan úniko. Ta importante pa mayornan sa kiko ta realístiko pa nan yunan hasi ora di duna nan instrukshon. Por ehèmpel, ta hopi difísil pa muchanan keda ketu henter un dia pero kisas nan por keda ketu pa 15 minüt miéntras nan mayornan ta hasi un yamada.

Tambe mucha ta tende mihó i ta komprondé e instrukshonnan bon kla ora mayornan ta papia ku un bos trankil. Uniko kos ku bo ta logra ku grita mucha, ta oumentá e tenshon pa tur hende. Ademas muchanan tin mas chèns di sigui instrukshonnan duná na un manera trankil.

Elogio ta un ekspreshon di aprobashon òf apresio. Ora mayornan elogiá nan yunan pa a sigui instrukshonnan, nan ta enkurashá e komportashon ei pa e pasa mas tantu. E mésun kos ta konta ora elogiá otro komportashonnan. Tambe, komportashon ku mayor ignorá tin ménos chèns di pasa atrobe.

Ku e ehèmpel ariba, un mayor por bisa, “Danki pa hinka bo ko’i hunga den e kaha, Joseph,” despues ku e sigui e instrukshon. Esaki lo animá Joseph pa sigui piki su ko’i hunganan den futuro. E ta mantené tambe un sintimentu positivo entre e mayor i Joseph.

**Key building blocks for giving instructions**

The key building blocks for giving instructions are Be Positive, Be Specific, and Be Real:

1️⃣ Know the positive behaviour you want to see from your child.
2️⃣ Make sure to have your child’s attention when giving an instruction.
3️⃣ Give one instruction at a time. 
4️⃣ Give your child time to follow each instruction.
4️⃣ Make sure your child is able to follow your instruction.
5️⃣ For younger children, break one big task into small ones and give instructions step by step. 
6️⃣ Praise your child immediately after following an instruction.

**Key building blocks for praise**

The key building blocks for Praise are SEE IT, SAY IT, REPEAT IT:

1️⃣ SEE IT. Notice anything your child does that is helpful or good and praise them. They may not show it, but you’ll see them doing that good thing again. It will also reassure them that you notice and care.

2️⃣SAY IT. Be enthusiastic - really mean it when you say it!

4️⃣ REPEAT IT. Try to find something every day to thank them for. Even something really small.
text:
**Komponentenan básiko i klave pa duna instrukshon**

E komponentenan básiko i klave pa duna instrukshon ta Ta Positivo, Ta Spesífiko, i Ta Realístiko:

1️⃣ Konosé e komportashon positivo ku bo ke mira serka bo yu.
2️⃣ Sòru pa bo tin atenshon di bo yu ora di duna instrukshon.
3️⃣ Duna instrukshon un pa un. 
4️⃣ Duna bo yu tempu pa sigui kada instrukshon.
4️⃣ Sigurá bo mes ku bo yu por sigui bo instrukshon.
5️⃣ Pa muchanan mas chikí, kibra un tarea grandi den tareanan chikí i duna instrukshon stap pa stap. 
6️⃣ Elogiá bo yu mésora despues di a sigui un instrukshon.

**Komponentenan básiko i klave pa elogio**

E komponentenan básiko i klave pa Elogio ta MIR'E, BIS'E, RIPITI'E:

1️⃣ MIR'E. Tuma nota di kualke kos ku bo yu ta hasi ku ta útil òf bon i elogi’é. E lo no lagá bo ripará, pero lo bo mir'é hasi e kos bon ei atrobe. Tambe, e lo bolbe sigurá nan ku bo tin atenshon i ta pèrkurá pa nan.

2️⃣BIS'E. Ta entusiasmá - realmente bis’é ku sinseridat!

4️⃣ RIPITI'E. Purba di haña algu tur dia pa gradisi'é p’e. Asta algu hopi chikí.

Parents sometimes get frustrated at their children for being noisy or not tidying up after they have played, throwing their food on the ground, or staying out way too late. Often children don’t understand why these things are important. Establishing and explaining household rules helps children understand what is expected of them and why. Rules also establish clear boundaries that help children to feel safe and secure.

Routines also help children to feel safe and secure. Routines such as mealtimes and bedtimes can help create a stable environment for children. This is especially important for those who are living in hectic or unsafe environments and communities. 

**In this module, parents focus on the importance of involving their children when establishing household rules and routines to help keep their children safe and healthy.**
text:
Mayornan tin bia ta keda frustrá ku nan yunan pasobra e yunan ta borotá òf no ta piki kos despues ku nan a hunga, nan ta tira nan kuminda abou òf ta keda pafó muchu lat. Hopi biaha muchanan no ta komprondé dikon e kosnan akí ta importante. Traha i splika reglanan di kas ta yuda muchanan komprondé kiko ta spera di nan i dikon. Reglanan tambe ta pone límitenan kla ku ta yuda muchanan sinti nan mes seif i sigur.

Rutinanan tambe ta yuda muchanan sinti nan mes seif i sigur. Rutinanan manera ora di kome i ora di drumi por yuda krea un ambiente stabil pa muchanan. Esaki ta spesialmente importante si bo ta biba den ambientenan i komunidatnan drùk òf ínsigur. 

**Den e módulo aki, mayornan ta enfoká riba e importansia di enbolbí nan yunan ora di traha reglanan i rutinanan di kas pa yuda tene nan yunan seif i salú.**

SourceText:
**Key building blocks for rules and routines**

The key building blocks for establishing household rules and routines are:

1️⃣ Be a Team. Create rules with your child or teenager. One rule at a time is easiest. Discuss the reasons for the rule and listen to their views. 

2️⃣ Keep It Real. Make them realistic for what your child or teenager can do and be clear and specific so there’s no misunderstanding. Not ‘on time’ but ‘by 7pm’. 

3️⃣ Be Consistent. Daily routines, such as time for schoolwork, play, meals, and sleep, can help our children feel safe and secure. They also give our children a sense of security that they need to grow and develop.

4️⃣ Praise, Praise, Praise. Praise your child or teen for making a rule with you and praise them for keeping it!

**Here are some more specific building blocks for creating household rules:**

1️⃣ Establish household rules when your child or teen is calm and quiet.
 
2️⃣ Make your household rules clear and specific.

3️⃣ Make your household rules fair and realistic.

4️⃣ Make sure your child understands the reason for the rule. Use open communication to help with this.

5️⃣ Allow your child or teen the chance to ask questions.

**Here are some more specific building blocks for creating daily routines**

1️⃣ Give children a transition warning before moving on to the next activity.

2️⃣ Describe the behaviour that you want your child to do by using positive words. 

3️⃣ Give one instruction at a time. Keep them simple and clear.

4️⃣ Praise your child for following through with each instruction. 

5️⃣ Bedtime and mealtime routines should be predictable and calm.

6️⃣ Make a schedule so caregivers can share responsibilities.
text:
**Komponentenan básiko i klave pa regla i rutina**

E komponentenan básiko i klave pa establesé regla i rutina di kas ta:

1️⃣ Ta un Tim. Krea reglanan huntu ku bo yu òf hóben. Un regla kada bes, ta mas fásil. Diskutí e motibunan di e regla i skucha su punto di bista. 

2️⃣ Ta Real. Hasi nan realístiko pa asina bo yu òf hóben por logra hasié i sea kla i spesífiko pa no tin mal komprondementu. No djis ‘na tempu’ pero ‘pa 7 or' di anochi’. 

3️⃣ Ta Konsistente. Rutinanan diario, manera tempu pa hùiswèrk, hunga, kome i drumi, por yuda nos yunan sinti nan mes seif i sigur. Tambe nan ta duna nos muchanan un sentido di seguridat ku nan mester pa krese i desaroyá.

4️⃣ Elogiá, elogiá, elogiá. Elogiá bo yu òf hóben pa a traha un regla ku bo i elogi'é pa a kumpli kuné!

**Aki tin algun komponentenan básiko mas spesífiko pa krea reglanan di kas:**

1️⃣ Traha reglanan di kas ora bo yu òf hóben ta trankil i ketu.
 
2️⃣ Hasi bo reglanan di kas kla i spesífiko.

3️⃣ Hasi bo reglanan di kas hustu i realístiko.

4️⃣ Sòru pa bo yu komprondé e motibu di e regla. Usa komunikashon habrí pa yuda ku esaki.

5️⃣ Permití bo yu òf tiner e chèns di hasi pregunta.

**Aki tin algun komponente básiko mas spesífiko pa krea rutinanan diario**

1️⃣ Duna muchanan un atvertensia di transishon promé ku pasa pa e siguiente aktividat.

2️⃣ Deskribí e komportashon ku bo ke pa bo yu mustra dor di usa palabranan positivo. 

3️⃣ Duna instrukshon un pa un. Tene nan simpel i kla.

4️⃣ Elogiá bo yu pa a sigui kada instrukshon. 

5️⃣ Rutinanan di ora di drumi i ora di kome mester ta predisibel i trankil.

6️⃣ Traha un skema di tempu pa asina dunadónan di kuido por kompartí responsabilidatnan.

SourceText:
There are lots of different ways for parents to encourage their children to behave well. In this programme we have already looked at one of these ways: praising the behaviour we would like to see more of. 

In this module we look at two other strategies for managing child behaviours: Redirecting and consequences. 

Redirecting is a strategy that is especially effective with younger children. When parents redirect their children from a negative behaviour to a positive behaviour at the beginning of the behaviour, they reduce the chance that the negative behaviour happens or grows into something more difficult to manage. This works especially well if parents then praise their children for the positive behaviour they end up doing. 

Consequences are the results of actions or behaviours. For example, not cleaning the dishes will result in not having a clean plate to eat from. Parents can use planned consequences with their children and teens when they forget or do not follow household rules. For example, if there is a household rule to come home before sunset and a child comes home late when out playing with friends, then an appropriate consequence could be that they cannot play with friends the next day.

Parents can involve their children and teens in planning consequences for certain behaviours. For example, they could discuss with their children what a consequence could be if they do not follow a certain household rule when they are creating it with them. 

Consequences can also be used when a child refuses to follow an instruction. Parents should first give a child a choice, for example, “Either you clear the table, or you will not be able to watch your favourite T.V. show.” This gives them a chance to comply and avoid receiving the consequence.
It is also important that parents make sure their consequences are reasonable and that they can follow through with them. Banning T.V. for the rest of the year or threatening to sell it is not something that parents can realistically do. It is also unfair!

We call strategies like redirect and consequences ‘positive discipline’ because they reinforce the positive relationship that parents are actively trying to build with their children by spending time together, praising and setting clear boundaries with rules.
text:
Tin hopi diferente manera pa mayornan enkurashá nan yunan pa komportá nan mes bon. Den e programa akí nos a mira un di e maneranan akí kaba: elogiá e komportashon ku nos lo kier mira mas tantu.

Den e módulo aki nos ta wak dos otro stratégia pa manehá komportashon di mucha: Desviá i konsekuensia.

Desviá ta un strategia ku ta spesialmente efektivo ku muchanan mas yòn. Ora mayornan desviá nan yunan for di un komportashon negativo pa un komportashon positivo na kuminsamentu di e komportashon, nan ta redusí e chèns ku e komportashon negativo ta sosodé òf ta bira algu mas difísil pa manehá. Esaki ta funshoná spesialmente bon si mayornan ta elogiá nan yunan pa e komportashon positivo ku nan ta hasi finalmente.

Konsekuensianan ta e resultadonan di akshonnan òf komportashon. Por ehèmpel, no laba e tayónan lo resultá den no tin un tayó limpi pa kome for di dje. Mayornan por usa konsekuensianan planiá ku nan muchanannan i hóbennan ora nan lubidá òf no ta sigui reglanan di kas. Por ehèmpel, si tin un regla di kas, pa bin kas promé ku solo baha i un mucha ta bin kas lat ora e bai hunga ku su amigunan, e ora ei un konsekuensia apropiá por ta ku e no por bai hunga ku su amigunan e siguiente dia.

Mayornan por enbolbí nan mucha i hóbennan den planifikashon di konsekuensianan pa sierto komportashonnan. Por ehèmpel, nan por papia ku nan yunan ora nan ta trahando regla, tokante kiko por ta un  konsekuensia si nan no kumpli ku un sierto regla di kas.

Por usa konsekuensianan tambe ora un mucha nenga di sigui un instrukshon. Mayornan mester duna un yu un eskoho promé, por ehèmpel, “Sea bo ta limpia e mesa òf lo bo no por wak bo programa di televishon faborito.” Esaki ta duna nan un chèns pa kumpli i evitá di haña konsekuensia. Tambe ta importante pa mayornan sòru pa nan konsekuensianan ta rasonabel i ku nan por implementá nan. Prohibí pa wak televishon pa sobrá di aña òf menasá di bende esaki no ta algu ku mayornan por hasi realístikamente. E ta inhusto tambe!

Nos ta yama stratégianan manera desviá i konsekuensianan, ‘disiplina positivo’ pasobra nan ta reforsá e relashon positivo ku mayornan ta purba konstruí aktivamente ku nan yunan dor di pasa tempu huntu, elogiá i pone límitenan kla ku reglanan.

SourceText:
**Key building blocks for positive discipline**

The key building blocks for Positive Discipline are Be Calm, Be Fair, and Be Positive:

1️⃣ Be Calm. The most important thing you can remember is to be calm when disciplining your child. Take a couple deep breaths or walk away if you need to. And then respond in a calm and clear way. 

2️⃣ Be Fair. Give your child a choice to comply before giving a consequence. For household rules, you can discuss consequences with your child or teen in advance. Make sure the consequence is reasonable and one you can follow through on.

3️⃣ Be Positive. Remember the Sunshine of Positive Attention! Try to avoid giving consequences in the first place by redirecting your child and giving lots of positive attention to the behaviours you want to see more of with plenty of praise. Make sure you involve your child in a positive activity after giving the consequence. 

**Here are some more specific building blocks for redirect:**

1️⃣ Use positive instructions to redirect your child from a negative to a positive behaviour.

2️⃣ Catch the behaviour before it occurs or early on!

3️⃣ Ignore the negative behaviour, not the child.

4️⃣ Use physical and verbal praise to support positive behaviour.

**Here are some more specific building blocks for consequences:**

1️⃣ Consequences can be used when children do not follow instructions or forget household rules.

2️⃣ Consequences should be specific, realistic, and reasonable.

3️⃣ Give a clear reason for the consequence. 

4️⃣ Introduce the consequence when both you and your child are calm and involve your child in deciding what the consequence should be.

5️⃣ When your child refuses to follow an instruction, give your child one last choice to comply before giving them a consequence.

6️⃣ When you give your child a consequence, you must follow through with it.
text:
**Komponentennan básiko klave pa disiplina positivo**

E komponentenan básiko pa Disiplina Positivo ta Ta Trankil, Ta Hustu, i Ta Positivo:

1️⃣ TaTrankil. E kos di mas importante ku bo por kòrda ta pa bo ta trankil ora bo ta disipliná bo yu. Hala rosea un par bia profundo òf kana bai si bo mester. I despues atendé kuné na un manera trankil i kla. 

2️⃣ Ta Hustu. Duna bo yu un opshon pa kumpli promé ku bo duna un konsekuensia. Pa reglanan di kas, bo por papia tokante konsekuensianan ku bo yu chikí òf hóben di antemano. Sòru pa e konsekuensia ta rasonabel i unu ku bo por ehekutá.
3️⃣ Ta Positivo. Kòrda e Brio di Solo, di Atenshon Positivo! Purba evitá pa duna konsekuensia na promé lugá dor di desvia bo yu fo'i un komportashon negativo i duna hopi atenshon positivo na e komportashonnan ku bo ke mira mas tantu dor di usa hopi elogio. Sòru pa bo enbolbí bo yu den un aktividat positivo despues di duna e konsekuensia. 

**Aki tin algun komponente básiko mas spesífiko pa desvia komportashon:**

1️⃣ Usa instrukshonnan positivo pa desvia bo yu for di un komportashon negativo pa un komportashon positivo.

2️⃣ Kapta e komportashon promé ku e sosodé òf kapt'é for di trempan!

3️⃣ Ignorá e komportashon negativo, no e mucha.

4️⃣ Usa elogio físiko i verbal pa enkurashá komportashon positivo.

**Aki tin algun komponente básiko mas spesífiko pa konsekuensia:**

1️⃣ Por usa konsekuensia ora e muchanan no ta sigui instrukshon òf ta lubidá reglanan di kas.

2️⃣ Konsekuensianan mester ta spesífiko, realístiko i rasonabel.

3️⃣ Duna un motibu kla pa e konsekuensia. 

4️⃣ Introdusí e konsekuensia ora tantu abo komo bo yu ta trankil i enbolbí bo yu den disidí kiko e konsekuensia lo mester ta.

5️⃣ Ora bo yu nenga di sigui un instrukshon, duna bo yu un último opshon pa kumpli promé ku dun'é un konsekuensia.

6️⃣ Ora bo duna bo yu un konsekuensia, bo mester ehekut'é.

The last module of the @global.app_name programme is about reflection and sharing. This final module is a bit longer than normal as you will help parents to reflect on their experiences during the programme and make specific plans on how they want to go forward without your facilitation.

The module starts with an opportunity to learn one final parenting skill – involving your children in solving problems. Throughout the entire programme, you have been modelling the key steps of solving problems with the parents.

There are 5 key steps in problem solving:
1️⃣ Identify the problem
2️⃣ Jointly come up with solutions
3️⃣ Choose a solution
4️⃣ Try the solution out
5️⃣ Reflect on whether the solution worked

Each week during the discussion on home activities and illustrated stories, the parents have used the same steps in problem solving to help identify and practice solutions to challenges experienced.

Teaching children how to solve their own problems is a skill that children will take with them for the rest of their lives. What a gift!

In the second part of the module, parents have the opportunity to reflect on the changes they have seen in their families and the experiences that they have had during the programme. They can share how they have changed and what they have noticed about how their children’s behaviours may have changed.

This is also an opportunity to discuss how parents can continue using the skills and building blocks they have practiced over the course of the programme. Weekly chats have enabled parents to get to know each other and to support each other. That support doesn’t need to end! With a new administrator of the group, the chat group can be used whenever anybody needs to reach out or check-in. 

This week’s programme objectives are therefore to reflect and identify how to keep the programme going in a parent-lead group. We cover these topics for just one day this week: today!
text:
E último módulo di e programa @global.app_name ta tokante reflekshoná i kompartí. E módulo final aki ta un tiki mas largu ku normal ya ku bo lo yuda mayornan reflehá riba nan eksperenshanan durante e programa i traha plannan spesífiko riba kon nan ke bai dilanti sin bo fasilitashon.

E módulo ta kuminsá ku un oportunidat pa siña un último abilidat di edukashon familiar – enbolbí bo yunan den solushoná problema. Durante henter e programa, bo a bin ta duna ehèmpel di e stapnan klave di solushoná problema ku e mayornan.

Tin 5 stap klave den solushoná problema:
1️⃣ Identifiká e problema
2️⃣ Bini ku solushonnan huntu
3️⃣ Skohe un solushon
4️⃣ Purba e solushon
5️⃣ Reflekshoná si e solushon a funshoná

Tur siman durante e diskushon riba aktividatnan na kas i historianan ilustrá, e mayornan a usa e mésun stapnan di solushoná problema pa yuda identifiká i praktiká solushonnan pa retonan ku nan a eksperenshá.

Siña muchanan kon pa solushoná nan mes problemanan ta un abilidat ku muchanan lo karga pa restu di nan bida. Esta un regalo!

Den e di dos parti di e módulo, mayornan tin e oportunidat pa reflekshoná riba e kambionan ku nan a mira den nan famia i e eksperenshanan ku nan a haña durante e programa. Nan por kompartí kon nan a kambia i kiko nan a nota di e posibel kambio di komportashon di nan yunan.
Esaki ta un oportunidat tambe pa papia tokante kon mayornan por sigui usa e abilidatnan i komponentenan básiko ku nan a praktiká durante e programa. 'Chat'nan semanal a permití mayornan siña konosé otro i sostené otro. E sosten ei no tin nodi di kaba! Ku un atministradó nobo di e grupo, semper por usa e grupo di 'chat' den kaso ku kualke hende ke papia òf hasi un 'chèk-in' ku otro.

Pues e ophetivonan di e programa di e siman akí ta pa reflehá i identifiká kon pa sigui ku e programa di grupo, dirigí pa un mayor. Nos ta kubri e tópikonan aki pa djis un dia e siman akí: awe!
